subject: Entrepreneurship
title: Sunk Cost Fallacy: Throwing Good Money After Bad
description: One-minute skill: Sunk Cost Fallacy: Throwing Good Money After Bad.

hook.text: Concorde flew for 27 years at a loss. Britain and France kept funding it because they'd already spent billions.

buildup.text: The sunk cost fallacy is continuing something because of past investment, not future value.

discovery.text: Rationally, spent money is gone. Only future costs and benefits should drive decisions.

twist.text: Founders fall hard for this. 'We've worked on this for two years' becomes a reason to keep going.

climax.text: Stewart Butterfield killed his video game twice. The leftover chat tool became Slackâ€”worth $27 billion.

punchline.text: What you've spent is gone. Only the future counts.

quiz.question: What is the sunk cost fallacy?
options: Continuing an action because of past investment rather than future value
Investing too much money in a single project
The tendency to underestimate future costs
